summary: This is an email from an FBI Assistant Legal Attaché in London to a recipient named Mandy, forwarding a response from UK authorities regarding travel records for subjects in the Epstein case. The UK indicates travel data is only retained for 5 years and suggests the FBI request Passenger Name Records (PNR) in the US for intelligence or submit an ILOR to UKCA for evidential travel data.

persons.name: Mandy
persons.context: Recipient of the email from the FBI Assistant Legal Attaché regarding travel record requests for subjects in the Epstein case.

persons.name: T/Senior Intelligence Officer
persons.role: Senior Intelligence Officer, Operations and Intelligence Directorate
persons.context: UK official who provided the response regarding retention of travel information and methods for the FBI to request travel data.

persons.name: Assistant Legal Attaché FBI/Legal Attaché Office
persons.context: Sender of the email, based at the American Embassy in London, coordinating with UK authorities on travel record requests related to the Epstein case.

connections.person1: Assistant Legal Attaché FBI/Legal Attaché Office

connections.person1: Assistant Legal Attaché FBI/Legal Attaché Office
connections.description: The FBI official is relaying a response from the UK Senior Intelligence Officer about travel data retention and request procedures.

events.title: Email regarding UK travel records request
events.description: FBI Assistant Legal Attaché in London emails Mandy with UK response about travel data retention and methods for obtaining travel records for subjects.
personsInvolved: Assistant Legal Attaché FBI/Legal Attaché Office

keyFacts: UK travel information is only retained for the last 5 years.
The FBI can request Passenger Name Records (PNR) in the US for intelligence purposes regarding subjects.
For evidential purposes, the FBI can submit an ILOR (International Letter of Request) to UKCA for 5-year travel data.
The communication shows ongoing investigative coordination between US and UK authorities regarding travel records in the Epstein case.
